Fine-grained control of RNG seeds in R

Like, why is ‘seedcatcher’ not already an R package?
Author

Danielle Navarro

Published

December 27, 2023

Literally 19 lines of code:

Seed <- R6::R6Class("Seed",
  public = list(
    initialize = function(...) {
      old <- .Random.seed
      set.seed(...)
      self$state <- eval(.Random.seed, envir = .GlobalEnv)
      assign(".Random.seed", old, envir = .GlobalEnv)
    },
    state = NULL,
    use = function(expr, envir = parent.frame()) {
      old <- .Random.seed
      assign(".Random.seed", self$state, envir = .GlobalEnv)
      x <- eval(substitute(expr), envir = envir)
      self$state <- eval(.Random.seed, envir = .GlobalEnv)
      assign(".Random.seed", old, envir = .GlobalEnv)
      return(x)
    }
  )
)

Lo and fucking behold bitch…

set.seed(1)
old <- .Random.seed
x <- Seed$new(1)
y <- Seed$new(1)
x$use(sample(10))
 [1]  9  4  7  1  2  5  3 10  6  8
y$use(sample(10))
 [1]  9  4  7  1  2  5  3 10  6  8
x$use(sample(10))
 [1]  3  1  5  8  2  6 10  9  4  7
y$use(sample(10))
 [1]  3  1  5  8  2  6 10  9  4  7
all.equal(old, .Random.seed)
[1] TRUE
